text:
Explore (Digging In)

Providing for Individual Needs

Monitor how students are organizing their data from their samples. Listen to how they are making sense of the samples and how it helps them to see the entire population.

Suggested Questions:

  • How are you making sure your samples are random?(Answers will vary. Should include replacing the blocks, mixing them up, drawing without looking)
  • How do you find the median? (middle number of the data)
  • How have we looked at proportions this year? (Answers will vary but they should be able to discuss how to use scale factors to make equivalent ratios.)
  • What does the box in a box plot tell you? (It is the interquartile range (IQR) or 50% of the data)

Planning for the Summary

What evidence will you use in the summary to clarify and deepen understanding of the Now What Do You Know Question? What will you do if you do not have evidence?

Now What Do You Know?

How can we use random sampling to estimate populations?

(As you are circulating during the Explore, listen to how students are making sense of using random samples. Find examples of samples that mirror the distribution of the population and those that donâ€™t to discuss in the summary.)
